acne.definition: Acne is a common skin condition that affects most people at some point. It causes spots, oily skin and sometimes skin that's hot or painful to touch. Usually appears on the face, back and chest.
acne.causes: Acne is caused when tiny holes in the skin, known as hair follicles, become blocked.
acne.consequences: Acne causes spots in your skin, such as blackheads, whiteheads, papules (small red bumps), pustules (similar to papules, but have a white tip in the centre, which is pus), nodules (large hard lumps that build beneath skin surface) and cysts (the most severe type of spot caused by acne).
acne.prevention:
Here's what you can do:
Don't wash affected areas of skin more than twice a day.
Wash the affected area with a mild soap or cleanser and lukewarm water. Very hot or cold water can make acne worse.
Don't try to 'clean out' blackheads or squeeze spots.
Avoid using too much make-up and cosmetics and make sure to remove them before you go to bed.
Wash your hair regularly and try to avoid letting your hair fall across your face.
And remember, treatment for acne depends on how severe it is and it can take several months of treatment before acne symptoms improve. You should talk to your doctor about the best treatment for you.

allergy.definition: An allergy üëÉ is a reaction the body has to a particular food or substance. Allergies are very common. The more common allergens include grass and polen, dust mites, food, insect bites and stings, medication, amongst others.
allergy.causes: Allergic reactions usually happen quickly within a few minutes of exposure to an allergen. These reactions can be sneezing, runny or blocked nose, red, itchy and watery eyes, wheezing and coughing and worsening of asthma or eczema symptoms.
allergy.consequences: If you suffer from an allergy, you're most likely to sneezing, have a runny or blocked nose, red, itchy, watery eyes, wheezing and coughing and worsening of asthma or eczema symptoms more often.
allergy.prevention:
The best way to keep your symptoms under control is often to avoid the things you're allergic to, although this isn't always practical.
Be careful about what you eat if you have food allergies.
Keep your pets outside as much as possible and wash them regularly if you have a pet allergy.
Keeping your home dry and well-ventilated, and dealing with any damp and condensation if the best way to avoid your mould alergy.
Use allergy-proof duvets and pillows, and fitting wooden floors rather than carpets if you're alergic to dust.
Medications for mild allergies are available from pharmacies without a prescription, but always ask your pharmacist or doctor for advice before starting any new medicine.

alzheimer.definition: Alzheimer's disease is the most common type of dementia, a progressive neurological disease which affects multiple brain functions, including memory.
alzheimer.causes: The exact cause of Alzheimer's disease is unknown, although a number of things are thought to increase your risk of developing the condition. These include increasing age, a family history of condition, previous severe head injuries and lifestyle factors and conditions associated with cardiovascular disease.
alzheimer.consequences: The first sign of Alzheimer's disease is usually minor memory problems. As the condition develops, memory problems become more severe and further symptoms can develop, such as difficulty planning or making decisions, problems moving around without assistance or performing self-care tasks and personality changes, such as becoming aggressive, demanding and suspicious of others.
alzheimer.prevention:
As the exact cause of Alzheimer's disease is still unknown, there's no way to prevent the condition. However, there are steps you can take that may help to delay the onset of dementia.
Reducing your risk of cardiovascular disease, by stop smoking, eat healthy and exercising every week.
Staying mentally active by reading, writing for pleasure, playing instruments, go out with friends, play your favorite sport, walk and do group activities.
Research into Alzheimer's disease is continuing. As more is revealed about the condition, other ways to treat or prevent it may be found.

angina.definition: Angina is a heart ‚ù§ condition caused by the blood supply to the heart muscle being restricted. This results in a pain felt in the throat or neck, jaw, shoulders, arms or in the back or stomach.
angina.causes:
Like all the body‚Äôs organs and tissues, your heart needs a constant supply of oxygen-rich blood to function normally.
Anything that causes the coronary arteries to narrow is a risk factor for both stable and unstable angina. Here are some risk factors:
- High blood pressure, related to being overweight, drinking excessive amounts of alcohol, smoking, lack of a balanced diet and exercise;
- High-fat diet and cholesterol;
- Lack of exercise;
- Smoking & Alcohol;
- Diabetes;
Age as the arteries tend to narrow over time.
angina.consequences:
The two main types of angina are stable angina and unstable angina.
Stable Angina - symptoms will usually develop gradually over time and follow a set pattern.Stable angina isn't life threatening on its own but is a sign that your arteries supplying blood to your heart muscle are narrowing. This means you have an increased risk of experiencing more serious conditions, such as a heart attack.
Unstable Angina - symptoms can develop rapidly and can persist even when you are at rest. They may continue for some time. Unstable angina should be regarded as a medical emergency because it is a sign that the blood supply to and the function of your heart is compromised, increasing your risk of having a heart attack.
angina.prevention: Maintaining an healthy life style is the best way to prevent heart diseases. On the other hand, exames like the Electrocardiogram (ECG), Exercise tolerance test (ETT), Myocardial perfusion scan (MPS or Myoview) and Coronary angiography may help you predict these conditions and change your lifestyle accordingly.

anorexia.definition: Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder and a serious, potentially life-threatening, mental health condition. People who have anorexia are very anxious about their weight and body shape. They try to keep their weight as low as possible by strictly controlling and limiting what they eat.
anorexia.causes:
The exact causes of anorexia nervosa are unclear, but most specialists believe it's likely to be the result of a combination of factors.
Psychological factors - Many people who develop anorexia share certain patterns of thinking and behaving that may make them more likely to develop the condition. These include depression and anxiety.
Environmental factors - Environmental factors are parts of the world around a person, and events happening in their life, that can affect their mental wellbeing in a variety of ways. Puberty can be an important factor contributing to anorexia and Western culture and society may also play a part.
Biological and genetic factors - Experts have suggested changes in brain function or hormone levels may also have a role in anorexia, although it's not clear if these lead to anorexia or if they develop later as a result of malnutrition.
anorexia.consequences:
If someone has anorexia for a long time, it can lead to severe complications and health problems that can sometimes be permanent.
People with anorexia have an increased risk of poor circulation and cardiovascular problems, heart conditions, such as coronary heart disease and irregular heartbeat and health problems caused by malnutrition ‚Äì a lack of vitamins and minerals.
anorexia.prevention:
Anorexia comes from 3 main symptoms - the fear of being fat, problems with self-esteem and restricting food intake and keeping your body weight low.
In order to prevent it, try talking to someone you trust, such as a friend or member of your family about this issue, or talk to your doctor about it.

anxiety.definition: Anxiety is a feeling of unease, such as worry or fear, that can be mild or severe. Anxiety is the main symptom of several conditions, including panic disorder, phobias, post-traumatic stress disorder and social anxiety disorder (social phobia).
anxiety.causes:
The exact cause of GAD (Generalised anxiety disorder) is not fully understood, although it's likely that a combination of several factors plays a role. Here are some examples
Overactivity in areas of the brain involved in emotions and behaviour;
Imbalance of the brain chemicals serotonin and noradrenaline, which are involved in the control and regulation of mood;
Genes you inherit from your parents ‚Äì you're estimated to be five times more likely to develop GAD if you have a close relative with the condition;
Having a history of stressful or traumatic experiences, such as domestic violence, child abuse or bullying;
Having a painful long-term health condition, such as arthritis;
Having a history of drug or alcohol misuse.
anxiety.consequences: Anxiety can have a significant effect on your daily life, leading to overactivity in areas of the brain involved in emotions and behaviour. This way you may feel worried and anxious about sitting an exam or having a medical test or job interview. Anxiety is the main symptom of several conditions, including panic disorder, phobias, post-traumatic stress disorder and social anxiety disorder.
anxiety.prevention:
Try Therapy which is one of the most effective treatments. It helps you understand how your problems, thoughts, feelings and behaviour affect each other. It can also help you to question your negative and anxious thoughts, and do things you would usually avoid because they make you anxious.
There's also applied relaxation, which focuses on relaxing your muscles in a particular way during situations that usually cause anxiety. The technique needs to be taught by a trained therapist, but generally involves learning how to relax your muscles and pratice it in situations that make you anxious.
Medication is also an option if the previous alternatives don't work. Depending on your symptoms, you may require medicine to treat your physical symptoms as well as your psychological ones. Nevertheless always ask your pharmacist or doctor for advice before starting any new medicine!
If you're feeling anxious right now, take a deep breath and think about something that makes your happy! Call a friend or a family member and talk to them about your problems. Mental help is super important. Take good care of yourself!

appendicitis.definition: Appendicitis is a painful swelling of the appendix. The appendix is a small, thin pouch about 5-10cm long. It's connected to the large intestine, where stools (üí©) are formed. Nobody knows exactly why we have an appendix, but removing it isn't harmful. Appendicitis typically starts with a pain in the middle of your tummy (abdomen) that may come and go.
appendicitis.causes: It's not exactly clear what the causes of appendicitis are. Most cases are thought to occur when something blocks the entrance of the appendix. This obstruction leads to the development of inflammation and swelling. The pressure caused by the swelling can then lead to the appendix bursting.
appendicitis.consequences: If you have appendicitis, your appendix usually needs to be removed as soon as possible. This operation is known as an appendectomy or appendicectomy. Appendectomies are carried out under general anaesthetic using either a keyhole or open technique. In most cases, you can return to normal activities in a couple of weeks, although more strenuous activities may need to be avoided for 4 to 6 weeks after surgery.
appendicitis.prevention:
As the causes aren't fully understood, there's no guaranteed way of preventing appendicitis. It's estimated around 1 in every 13 people develop it at some point in their life.
You should seek medical advice if you notice:
- Increasing pain and swelling;
- You start vomiting repeatedly;
- A high temperature (fever);
- Any discharge coming from the wound or if the wound is hot to touch
These symptoms could be a sign of infection.

arthritis.definition:
Arthritis is a common condition that causes pain and inflammation in a joint. In the UK, around 10 million people have arthritis. It affects people of all ages, including children. The two most common types of arthritis are:
Osteoarthritis - affects the smooth cartilage lining of the joint. This makes movement more difficult than usual, leading to pain and stiffness.
Rheumatoid arthritis - occurs when the body's immune system targets affected joints, which leads to pain and swelling.
arthritis.causes: The cause of the illness depends on the type of Arthritis. If you want to know more about this, let's talk about osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis and I can tell you about the causes, consequences and how to prevent it!
arthritis.consequences: The cause of the illness depends on the type of Arthritis. If you want to know more about this, let's talk about osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis and I can tell you about the causes, consequences and how to prevent it
arthritis.prevention:
There's no cure for arthritis, but there are many treatments that can help slow down the condition.
For osteoarthritis, medications are often prescribed, including painkillers or corticosteroids. In more severe cases surgical procedures may be recommended.
Treatment for rheumatoid arthritis aims to slow down the condition's progress and minimise joint inflammation or swelling. Recommended treatments include analgesics (painkillers) and physiotherapy.

asbestosis.definition: Asbestosis is a chronic lung condition caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos. Asbestos is a general term for a group of minerals made of microscopic fibres and they can be very dangerous. It does not present a health risk if it is undisturbed, but if material containing asbestos is chipped, drilled, broken or allowed to deteriorate, it can release a fine dust that contains asbestos fibres.
asbestosis.causes: Asbestosis is caused by breathing in asbestos fibres. People working in certain trades are more likely to have been exposed to asbestos in the past.asbestos fibres are too difficult for the macrophages to break down. In an attempt to break down the fibres, the macrophages release substances that are intended to destroy the fibres, but actually cause the tiny air sacs in your lungs (alveoli) to become damaged and permanently scarred over time. This scarring is what is known as asbestosis.
asbestosis.consequences:
Asbestosis is a relatively rare condition but there is no cure for it, as the damage to the lungs is irreversible. However, you can take steps to reduce your symptoms and improve your quality of life, such as:
- Do not smoke;
- Don't skip vaccination (flu, for example);
- Try long-term oxygen therapy.
asbestosis.prevention:
It's important to take precautions to reduce your risk of inhaling asbestos fibres if you live or work in a building that may contain asbestos. If you are concerned that your house may contain asbestos, ask for help from an environmental health officer at your local authority and don't try to remove anything by yourself.
If your job means you could potentially be exposed to asbestos fibres, make sure you are fully aware of what you can do to reduce your risk.

asthma.definition: Asthma ‚òÅ is a common long-term condition that can cause coughing, wheezing, chest tightness and breathlessness. The severity of these symptoms varies from person to person. Asthma can be controlled well in most people most of the time, although some people may have more persistent problems.
asthma.causes: Asthma is caused by inflammation of the small tubes, called bronchi, which carry air in and out of the lungs. If you have asthma, the bronchi will be inflamed and more sensitive than normal. Common asthma triggers include house dust mites, animal fur, pollen and cigarette smoke.
asthma.consequences: Asthma symptoms are usually controllable and reversible with treatment, although some people with long-lasting asthma may develop permanent narrowing of their airways and more persistent problems. Inhalers will now be part of your day in order to keep it controlled and let you enjoy your life.
asthma.prevention:
Asthma is usually prevented using inhalers.
Reliever Inhalers - Reliever inhalers ‚Äì usually blue ‚Äì are taken to relieve asthma symptoms quickly. The inhaler usually contains a medicine called a short-acting beta2-agonist, which works by relaxing the muscles surrounding the narrowed airways. This allows the airways to open wider, making it easier to breathe again.
Preventer Inhalers - Preventer inhalers ‚Äì usually brown, red or orange ‚Äì work over time to reduce the amount of inflammation and sensitivity of the airways, and reduce the chances of asthma attacks occurring. They must be used regularly (typically twice or occasionally once daily) and indefinitely to keep asthma under control.
Long-acting reliever inhalers - These work in the same way as short-acting relievers. Although they take slightly longer to work, their effects can last for up to 12 hours. This means that taking them regularly twice a day provides 24-hour cover.

bipolar disorder.definition: Bipolar disorder, formerly known as manic depression, is a condition that affects your moods, which can swing from one extreme to another. People with bipolar disorder have periods or episodes of depression (feeling very low and lethargic üò¢) and mania (feeling very high and overactive ü•≥).
bipolar disorder.causes:
The exact cause of bipolar disorder is unknown. Experts believe there are a number of factors that work together to make a person more likely to develop the condition.
Chemical imbalance in the brain - There's some evidence that if there's an imbalance in the levels of one or more neurotransmitters, a person may develop some symptoms of bipolar disorder.
Genetics - It's also thought bipolar disorder is linked to genetics, as the condition seems to run in families.
Triggers - A stressful circumstance or situation often triggers the symptoms of bipolar disorder, such as the breakdown of a relationship or physical, sexual or emotional abuse.
bipolar disorder.consequences: Bipolar disorder is characterised by extreme mood swings. These can range from extreme highs (mania) to extreme lows (depression). The consequences of having bipolar disorder is swinging between these moods. You may have episodes of depression more regularly than episodes of mania, or vice versa. On the other hand, you may sometimes have periods where you have a 'normal' mood between those.
bipolar disorder.prevention: The exact cause of bipolar disorder is unknown, although it's believed a number of things can trigger an episode. The proper way to prevent having it is avoiding extreme stress and overwhelming problems. On the other hand, when life-changing events occur, make sure you ask for help.

bone cancer.definition: Primary bone ü¶¥ cancer is a rare type of cancer that begins in the bones. This is a separate condition from secondary bone cancer, which is cancer that spreads to the bones after developing in another part of the body.
bone cancer.causes: Cancer occurs when the cells in a certain area of your body divide and multiply too rapidly. This produces a lump of tissue known as a tumour.The exact reason why this happens is often not known, but certain things can increase your chance of developing the condition, including previous radiotherapy treatment, other bone conditions (Paget‚Äôs disease) or rare genetic conditions.
bone cancer.consequences:
Treatment for bone cancer depends on the type of bone cancer you have and how far it has spread.
- Surgery to remove the section of cancerous bone;
- Chemotherapy and radiotherapy;
- In some cases of osteosarcoma, a medication called mifamurtide may also be recommended.
bone cancer.prevention: The outlook for bone cancer depends on factors such as your age, the type of bone cancer you have, how far the cancer has spread (the stage), and how likely it is to spread further. Generally, bone cancer is much easier to cure in otherwise healthy people whose cancer hasn't spread.

brain tumour.definition: A brain tumour is a growth of cells in the brain that multiplies in an abnormal, uncontrollable way. It can either be cancerous (malignant) or non-cancerous (benign). They are graded from 1 to 4 according to their behaviour, such as how fast they grow and how likely they are to grow back after treatment.
brain tumour.causes: Most malignant brain tumours are caused by a cancer that started somewhere else in the body and spread to the brain, through the bloodstream. Cancers that can spread to the brain include lung cancer, breast cancer, bowel cancer and melanoma skin cancer.
brain tumour.consequences:
Having a brain tumour can lead to several conditions, such as severe and persistent headaches, seizures and/or nausea, mental or behavioural changes and progressive weakness or paralysis on one side of the body, vision problems, or speech problems.
If you have a malignant brain tumour, you'll usually need surgery to remove as much of it as possible. The aim of this is to remove or destroy as much of the tumour as possible, ideally getting rid of the cancerous cells completely.
brain tumour.prevention: The exact cause of primary malignant brain tumours is unknown, although it's thought that certain genetic conditions and previous radiotherapy treatment to the head may increase the risk of one developing.

breast cancer.definition: Breast cancer is the most common type of cancer in the UK. If it's treated early enough, breast cancer can be prevented from spreading to other parts of the body. The breasts are made up of thousands of tiny glands called lobules, which produce milk. When a woman has a baby, the milk is delivered to the nipple which allow her to breastfeed. The body is made up of billions of tiny cells, which usually grow and multiply in an orderly way. New cells are only produced when and where they're needed. In cancer, this orderly process goes wrong and cells begin to grow and multiply uncontrollably.
breast cancer.causes:
The causes of breast cancer aren't fully understood, making it difficult to say why one woman may develop breast cancer and another may not. However, there are risk factors that are known to affect your likelihood of developing breast cancer. Some of these you can't do anything about, but there are some you can change, such as age and family history.
If you've previously had breast cancer or early non-invasive cancer cell changes in breast ducts, you have a higher risk of developing it again.
A benign breast lump doesn't mean you have breast cancer, but certain types of lump may slightly increase your risk of developing it.
breast cancer.consequences:
Surgery is usually the first type of treatment for breast cancer, depending on the type of breast cancer. These envolve removing the tumour, Breast-conserving surgery, or the emoval of all the breast tissue, including the nipple, Mastectomy, that can be followed by a reconstruction.
Secondary cancer, 'advanced' or 'metastatic', isn't curable and treatment aims to achieve remission.
Getting back to normal after surgery can take some time and it's important to take things slowly. During this time, avoid lifting things and doing heavy housework.
breast cancer.prevention:
Some treatments are available to reduce the risk in women who have a higher risk of developing the condition than the general population. Nevertheless, there are some ways to prevent female breast cancer:
- Diet and lifestyle;
- Breastfeeding;
- Treatments to reduce your risk, as Mastectomy and Medication.

bronchitis.definition: Bronchitis is an infection of the main airways of the lungs (bronchi), causing them to become irritated and inflamed. The main symptom is a cough, which may bring up yellow-grey mucus. Bronchitis may also cause a sore throat and wheezing.
bronchitis.causes: The bronchitis infection can be caused by either a virus or bacteria, although viral bronchitis is much more common. In most cases, bronchitis is caused by the same viruses that cause the common cold or flu. Bronchitis can also be triggered by breathing in irritant substances, such as smog, chemicals in household products or tobacco smoke.
bronchitis.consequences:
Most cases of bronchitis can be easily managed at home. Getting enough rest, drinking lots of fluids and treating headaches, fever and aches with paracetamol or ibuprofen is more than enough to manage bronchitis symptoms.
If you smoke, you should stop immediately. Smoking aggravates bronchitis and increases your risk of developing a long-term (chronic) condition.
bronchitis.prevention:
Smoking is the most common cause of chronic bronchitis. Over time, tobacco smoke can cause permanent damage to the bronchi, causing them to become inflamed.
Bronchitis can also be triggered by breathing in irritant substances and avoiding them would be the best way to prevent it.

bulimia.definition: Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder and mental health condition. People who have bulimia try to control their weight by severely restricting the amount of food they eat. As with other eating disorders, bulimia nervosa can be associated with low self-esteem, alcohol misuse, depression or self-harm.
bulimia.causes:
There is no simple answer to the question of what causes bulimia. Although the condition is linked to a fear of getting fat, more complex emotions usually contribute. Common problems that may lead to bulimia include low self esteem, depression and stress.
Other mental health problems like anxiety disorders, OCD, PTSD and personality disorders are often linked to bulimia.
bulimia.consequences:
Anyone can recover from bulimia, but it may be a long and difficult process. The first step towards getting better is to recognise the problem and have a genuine desire to get well.
Psychological treatment is very important. It usually envolves Cognitive behavioural therapy or Interpersonal therapy.
Medication like Antidepressants known as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may be used to treat bulimia.
Bulimia is not usually treated in hospital. However, if you have serious health complications and your life is at risk, you may be admitted to hospital.
bulimia.prevention:
As with all eating disorders, women are much more likely to develop bulimia than men. If you have an eating disorder such as bulimia, the first step is to recognise that you have a problem. Then, you needa medical check-up for advice on how to get treatment.
Signs of bulimia nervosa include an obsessive attitude towards food and eating, an overcritical attitude to weight and shape, and frequent visits to the bathroom after eating, in order to force vomiting.

cellulitis.definition: Cellulitis is an infection of the deeper layers of skin and the underlying tissue. It can be serious if not treated promptly. The infection develops suddenly and can spread through the body quickly. Severe infections can spread deep into the body, and can be life threatening.
cellulitis.causes:
Cellulitis is usually caused by a bacterial infection. It occurs when bacteria get into the tissues beneath the skin. The bacteria that cause cellulitis often live harmlessly on the skin. But if the surface of your skin is damaged, they can get into the layers underneath and cause an infection.
Often causes are cuts or gaze, burns, animal, insect or human bites.
Anyone can get cellulitis, but the risk increases if someone is obese, has poor circulation in legs/arms/feet or has a weakened immune system.
cellulitis.consequences:
Cellulitis can often be treated at home with a course of antibiotics, although severe cases may need to be treated in hospital.
If the treatment takes place at home, you'll usually be prescribed antibiotic tablets to take two to four times a day for a week. Your symptoms may get worse in the first 48 hours after treatment starts, but should start to improve soon afterwards.
If you need to be admitted to hospital for treatment, you'll be given antibiotics directly into a vein through an injection or a drip.
cellulitis.prevention:
If you've had cellulitis before, you're more likely to get it again. It's not always possible to prevent it but there are a few things that can be done, such as:- lose weight if you're overweight;
- try to ensure any conditions that can increase your risk of cellulitis are well managed;
- make sure any cuts, grazes or bites are kept clean;
- wash your hands regularly!

chest pain.definition:
Chest pain can be caused by anything from muscle pain to a heart attack and should never be ignored. If you feel/have recently felt these symptons, call your emergency number immediately:
- the pain feels heavy, pressing or tight;
- the pain lasts longer than 15 minutes;
- the pain spreads to other parts of your body, such as your arms, back or jaw;
- shortness of breath, nausa, sweating or coughing up blood.
chest pain.causes:
The common causes of chest pain are not heart-related and isn't a sign of a life-threatening problem. Here are some:
- Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) - condition where acid from the stomach comes up into the oesophagus;
- Bone or muscle problems - If your chest is painful and tender to touch, it may be caused by a strained muscle in your chest wall;
- Anxiety and panic attacks;
- Lung conditions - If you have sharp chest pain that gets worse when you breathe in and out, and is accompanied by other symptoms such as a cough and breathlessness, it may be caused by a condition affecting the lungs or surrounding tissue.
chest pain.consequences: Chest pain isn't always caused by a problem with your heart, but it can sometimes be a symptom of angina (blood supply in the heart is restricted) and a heart attack. In these cases, your life is under risk and you should call your emergency number and ask for an ambulance.
chest pain.prevention: In order to prevent such conditions, you should adopt an healthy lifestyle, balancing a good diet with a good amount of weekly exercise. Decreasing the sources of your stress can also help you live a better life and keep these problems away from you.

coma.definition: A coma is a state of unconsciousness where a person is unresponsive and cannot be woken.
coma.causes:
A coma can result from injury to the brain, such as a severe head injury or stroke but can also be caused by severe alcohol poisoning or a brain infection (encephalitis).
People with diabetes could fall into a coma if their blood glucose levels suddenly became very low (hypoglycaemia) or very high (hyperglycaemia).
coma.consequences:
Someone who is in a coma is unconscious and has minimal brain activity. They're alive, but can't be woken up and show no signs of being aware.
Someone in a coma will also have very reduced basic reflexes such as coughing and swallowing. They may be able to breathe on their own, although some people require a machine to help them breathe.
Over time, the person may start to gradually regain consciousness and become more aware. Some people will wake up after a few weeks, while others may go into a vegetative state or minimally conscious state.
coma.prevention:
A coma is an condition that happens prior to an injury.
Worth mentioning that a coma can also be Medically Induced. This type of temporary coma, or deep state of unconsciousness, is used to protect the brain from swelling after an injury.
coma.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/brain-nerves-and-spinal-cord/coma' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

cold.definition:
A cold is a mild viral infection of the nose, throat, sinuses and upper airways. It's very common and usually clears up on its own within a week or two.
The main symptoms include a sore throat, a blocked or runny nose, sneezing and a cough.
More severe symptoms might include fever and headaches.
cold.causes:
In general, a person becomes contagious from a few days before their symptoms begin until all of their symptoms have gone. You can catch the virus from an infectious person by touching an object or surface contaminated by infected droplets and then touching your mouth, nose or eyes, touching the skin of someone who has the infected droplets on their skin or inhaling tiny droplets of fluid that contain the cold virus.
Colds spread most easily among groups of people in constant close contact, such as families and children in school or day care facilities.
cold.consequences:
Colds usually clear up without causing any further problems. However, the infection can sometimes spread to your chest, ears or sinuses.
Sinusitis is an infection of the small air-filled cavities inside the cheekbones and forehead. It develops in up to 1 in every 50 adults and older children who have a cold.
Middle ear infection (otitis media) includes severe earache, high temperatures, flu-like symptons and some loss of hearing.
Chest infections such as bronchitis and pneumonia can occur after a cold, as your immune system is temporarily weakened. Symptoms of a chest infection include a persistent cough, bringing up mucus, and shortness of breath.
cold.prevention:
Prevent a common cold is difficult, since anyone can have it, but there are a few steps you can take, such as:
- wash your hands regularly;
- always sneeze and cough into tissues;
- clean surfaces regularly to keep them free of germs;
- use your own cup, plates, cutlery and kitchen utensils;
- don't share towels or toys with someone who has a cold.
If you have a cold, you can easily take care of it by resting, drinking plenty of fluids and eating healthily, taking over-the-counter painkillers, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen, to reduce any fever or discomfort and using decongestant sprays or tablets to relieve a blocked nose.
cold.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/infections-and-poisoning/common-cold' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

conjunctivitis.definition: Conjunctivitis is a common condition that causes redness and inflammation of the thin layer of tissue that covers the front of the eye. Other symptoms of conjunctivitis include itchiness and watering of the eyes, and sometimes a sticky coating on the eyelashes.
conjunctivitis.causes: The conjunctiva (thin layer of tissue that covers the front of the eye) can become inflamed as a result of a bacterial or viral infection (infective conjunctivitis), you're more likely to develop infective conjunctivitis if you've been in close contact with someone who's already infected with it, an allergic reaction to a substance such as pollen or dust mites (allergic conjunctivitis) or by the eye coming into contact with things that can irritate the conjunctiva, such as shampoo or chlorinated water, or a loose eyelash rubbing against the eye (irritant conjunctivitis).
conjunctivitis.consequences:
Treatment isn't usually needed for conjunctivitis, because the symptoms often clear up within a couple of weeks. If treatment is needed, the type of treatment will depend on the cause. In severe cases, antibiotic eye drops can be used to clear the infection.
- Irritant conjunctivitis will clear up as soon as whatever is causing it is removed;
- Allergic conjunctivitis can usually be treated with anti-allergy medications such as antihistamines;
- Infective conjunctivitis can be treated using antibiotics or by using lubricant eye drops.
Removing contact lenses and washing your hands regularly will also prevent the infection from spreading to others.
conjunctivitis.prevention:
Washing your hands regularly and not sharing pillows or towels will help prevent conjunctivitis from spreading.
Avoiding the substance that triggers the allergy, in case of an allergic conjunctivitis, helps preventing it as well.
conjunctivitis.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/eyes/conjunctivitis' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

constipation.definition:
Constipation is a common condition that affects people of all ages. It can mean that you're not passing stools regularly or you're unable to completely empty your bowel.
Constipation can also cause your stools to be hard and lumpy, as well as unusually large or small.
constipation.causes:
Constipation usually occurs when stools remain in the colon for too long, and the colon absorbs too much water from the stools, causing them to become hard and dry.
Although it may be difficult to identify the exact cause several factors can increase your chances of having constipation, including:
- Not eating enough fiber (fruit, cereals, vegetables);
- Not drinking enough fluids;
- Anxiety or depression
- Ignoring the urge to pass stools.
constipation.consequences:
Treatment for constipation depends on the cause, how long you've had it and how severe your symptoms are. In many cases, it's possible to relieve the symptoms by making dietary and lifestyle changes. Here are some self-help methods you can follow:
- Increase your daily intake of fibre;
- Avoid dehydration by drinking plenty of water;
- Add some bulking agents, such as wheat bran, to your diet. This will help to make your stools softer and easier to pass;
- Exercise more regularly and keep to a routine when you're able to spend time on the toilet.
constipation.prevention:
There are a number of things you can do to prevent constipation, including making diet and lifestyle changes.
- Including enough fibre (fruit, vegetables, rice, pasta, bread and oats) in your diet can significantly reduce your chances of developing constipation.
- Make sure you drink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration, and steadily increase your intake when exercising or when it's hot.
- Never ignore the urge to go to the toilet, because it can significantly increase your chances of having constipation.
constipation.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/stomach-liver-and-gastrointestinal-tract/constipation' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

coronavirus.definition: Coronavirus (COVID-19) is the illness caused by a new strain of coronavirus first identified in Wuhan city, China. It can cause a new continuous cough, fever or loss of, or change in, sense of smell or taste.
coronavirus.causes: People can become infected when droplets land directly on them or they touch contaminated objects and surfaces. That is why good respiratory hygiene and hand washing are so important.
coronavirus.consequences:
The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, tiredness, and dry cough. Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, or sore throat. These symptoms are usually mild and begin gradually.
Most people, according to WHO, recover from the disease without needing special treatment, and for the majority ‚Äì especially for children and young adults ‚Äì illness due to COVID-19 is generally minor.
Make sure you keep tracking your symptoms and if they get any worse, call your doctor right away or the national emergency number.
coronavirus.prevention:
Physical distancing measures are things you should do to reduce how often you interact with others outside your household. This will stop coronavirus (COVID-19) spreading.
Whenever you have to leave your place, make sure you wear a mask and wash your hands afterwards.
coronavirus.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

cough.definition: A cough is a reflex action to clear your airways of mucus and irritants such as dust or smoke. It's rarely a sign of anything serious. A 'dry cough' means it's tickly and doesn't produce any phlegm (thick mucus). A 'chesty cough' means phlegm is produced to help clear your airways.
cough.causes:
Common causes of a short-term cough include an upper respiratory tract infection that affects the throat, windpipe or sinuses (cold, flu, laryngitis), a lower respiratory tract infection that affects your lungs or lower airways (bronchitis or pneumonia), an allergy or inhaled dust or smoke.
A persistent cough may be caused by a long-term respiratory tract infection, such as chronic bronchitis, smoking, asthma, allergies. Rarely, a persistent cough can be a symptom of a more serious condition, such as lung cancer, heart failure, a pulmonary embolism or tuberculosis.
cough.consequences: Most coughs clear up within three weeks and don't require any treatment. For more persistent coughs, it's a good idea to see your doctor in order to investigate the cause.
cough.prevention: Treatment isn't always necessary for short-term coughs because it's likely to be a viral infection that will get better on its own within a few weeks. You can look after yourself at home by resting, drinking plenty of fluids, and taking painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen.
cough.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/lungs-and-airways/cough' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

cystic fibrosis.definition:
Cystic fibrosis is an inherited condition in which the lungs and digestive system can become clogged with thick, sticky mucus.
It can cause problems with breathing and digestion from a young age. Over many years, the lungs become increasingly damaged and may eventually stop working properly.
cystic fibrosis.causes:
Cystic fibrosis is caused by a faulty gene that a child inherits from both their parents. The faulty gene means that some cells struggle to move salt and water across the cell wall. This, along with recurrent infections, can result in a build-up of thick, sticky mucus in the body's tubes and passageways ‚Äì particularly the lungs and digestive system.
The condition is present from birth and cannot be caught from someone else who has it.
cystic fibrosis.consequences: People with cystic fibrosis tend to have recurring chest infections, difficulty putting on weight, frequent,wet-sounding coughs, diarrhoea and occasional wheezing and shortness of breath. People with the condition can also develop a number of related conditions, including diabetes, thin, weakened bones and liver problems.
cystic fibrosis.prevention:
There's currently no cure for cystic fibrosis, but it's possible to help control the symptoms, prevent or reduce complications, and make the condition easier to live with.
People with cystic fibrosis may need to take a number of different medicines to treat and prevent lung problems.
In addition to medication, special techniques can be used to help keep the lungs and airways clear. A physiotherpist can give you advice.
For people with cystic fibrosis, getting the right nutrition is vital in helping them develop normally and stopping them becoming frequently ill. Therefore, Dietary and nutritional advice are necessary.
cystic fibrosis.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/lungs-and-airways/cystic-fibrosis' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

dehydration.definition:
Dehydration occurs when your body loses more fluid than you take in. When the normal water content of your body is reduced, it upsets the balance of minerals in your body, which affects the way it functions.
Some of the early warning signs of dehydration include feeling thirsty and lightheaded, a drymouth, tiredness or having dark coloured, strong-smelling urine.
dehydration.causes:
Dehydration is usually caused by not drinking enough fluid to replace what we lose. The climate, the amount of physical exercise you are doing and your diet can contribute to dehydration.
You can also become dehydrated as a result of an illness, such as persistent vomiting and diarrhoea, or sweating from a fever.
dehydration.consequences: The best way to treat dehydration is to rehydrate the body by drinking plenty of fluids, such as water, diluted squash or diluted fruit juice. A sweet drink can help to replace lost sugar, and a salty snack can help to replace lost salt.
dehydration.prevention:
You should drink plenty of fluids to avoid becoming dehydrated. Most of the time, you can prevent dehydration by drinking water regularly throughout the day.
If you, your child or someone you are caring for is ill, particularly with a fever, vomiting or diarrhoea, there's a high risk of becoming dehydrated, so it's important to start replacing fluid as soon as possible.
dehydration.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/nutritional/dehydration#preventing-dehydration' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

dementia.definition:
Dementia is a common condition. Your risk of developing dementia increases as you get older, and the condition usually occurs in people over the age of 65.
Dementia is a syndrome associated with an ongoing decline of the brain and its abilities. This includes problems with memory loss, thinking speed, mental agility, language and understanding.
dementia.causes:
Dementia is caused by gradual changes and damage in the brain. The most common causes of dementia include diseases in which the brain cells degenerate and die more quickly than they would as part of the normal ageing process.
This damage leads to a decline in a person's mental and, sometimes, physical abilities.
dementia.consequences:
Most types of dementia cannot be cured and will gradually cause more severe problems. But there are important exceptions, including dementia caused by vitamin and thyroid hormone deficiencies, which can be treated with supplements.
For dementia that currently cannot be cured, some types of medicine may prevent symptoms getting worse for a period of time. These medicines are usually given to people in the early and middle stages of the disease, to try to maintain or improve their independence.
dementia.prevention:
There is no certain way to prevent all types of dementia. However, a healthy lifestyle can help lower your risk of developing dementia when you are older. It can also prevent cardiovascular diseases, such as strokes and heart attacks.
To reduce your risk of developing dementia and other serious health conditions, it's recommended that you eat a healthy diet, maintain a healthy weight and exercise regularly and make sure to keep your blood pressure at a healthy level.
dementia.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/brain-nerves-and-spinal-cord/dementia' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

depression.definition: Everyone can be feeling down sometimes, but depression is more than just spending a few days feeling sad or unhappy. Depression can make you feel persistently sad and down for weeks or months at a time.
depression.causes:
Depression doesn't have one single cause ‚Äì it can have a range of triggers, and there are many different reasons a person can develop the condition.
Long-lasting or life-threatening conditions like cancer or coronary heart disease can put you at higher risk of developing depression.
Alcohol is categorised as a 'strong depressant' which can make depression worse, and drinking or taking drugs to cope can lead to a downward spiral by having a negative affect on other parts of your life.
Stressful events, giving birth, loneliness and family history are also causes for depression.
depression.consequences:
There's a lot of advice available for living with depression and feeling better.
Talking about depression with another person or a group if a way you can find support and insight.
It might feel like cigarettes and alcohol are helpful, but in the long run they can make you feel worse. Smoking, drugs, alcohol and depression are a few things you should be avoiding.
You might need to take time off work if your depression is caused by working too much, or if the symptoms are making it hard for you to do your job.
Along with time, the right help and support can make it possible to start living your life again.
depression.prevention:
Big, stressful events like divorce, serious illness, financial worries, or bereavement can trigger depression for some people.
Depression has a range of different symptoms, and it can affect everybody differently.
The best way to prevent depression is to take good care of yourself. Get enough sleep, eat well, and exercise regularly.
depression.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/mental-health/depression' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

diabetes.definition:
Diabetes is a lifelong condition that causes a person's blood glucose level to become too high.
There are two main types of diabetes ‚Äì type 1 diabetes (body's immune system attacks and destroys the cells that produce insulin) and type 2 diabetes (the body doesn't produce enough insulin, or the body's cells don't react to insulin).
diabetes.causes: The amount of glucose in the blood is controlled by a hormone called insulin, which is produced by the pancreas. When food is digested insulin moves glucose out of the blood and into cells, where it's broken down to produce energy. However, if you have diabetes, your body is unable to break down glucose into energy because there's either not enough insulin to move the glucose, or the insulin produced doesn't work properly.
diabetes.consequences: Check Type 1 Diabetes or Type 2 Diabetes for more information :)
diabetes.prevention: Check Type 1 Diabetes or Type 2 Diabetes for more information :)
diabetes.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/diabetes/diabetes' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

diarrhoea.definition: Diarrhoea is passing looser or more frequent stools than is normal for you. It affects most people from time to time and is usually nothing to worry about. However, it can be distressing and unpleasant until it passes, which normally takes a few days to a week.
diarrhoea.causes:
There are many different causes of diarrhoea, but a bowel infection (gastroenteritis) is a common cause in both adults and children. Gastroenteritis can be caused by a virus, a bacteria or a parasite.
Diarrhoea can also be the result of anxiety, a food allergy, medication, or a long-term condition.
diarrhoea.consequences:
Diarrhoea will usually clear up without treatment after a few days, particularly if it's caused by an infection.
In children, diarrhoea will usually pass within 5 to 7 days and will rarely last longer than 2 weeks.
In adults, diarrhoea usually improves within 2 to 4 days, although some infections can last a week or more.
While waiting for your diarrhoea to pass, you can ease your symptoms by drinking fluids, eat small, light meals and avoid fatty or spicy foods.
You can also go for medication, like Antidiarrhoeal medicines which may help reduce your diarrhoea and slightly shorten how long it lasts.
diarrhoea.prevention:
To prevent the spread of infections that cause diarrhoea, you should always maintain high standards of hygiene.
- Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water after going to the toilet and before eating or preparing food.
- Clean the toilet, including the handle and the seat, with disinfectant after each bout of diarrhoea.
- Avoid sharing towels, flannels, cutlery or utensils with others.
- Wash soiled clothing and bed linen separately from other clothes and at the highest temperature possible.
diarrhoea.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/stomach-liver-and-gastrointestinal-tract/diarrhoea#about-diarrhoea' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

down's syndrome.definition:
A baby with Down's syndrome is born with more of chromosome 21 in some or all of their cells. It's also known as Trisomy 21.
People with the condition may lead active, healthy and independent lives into their 60s, 70s and beyond. Most will have mild to moderate learning disabilities and some may have more complex needs.
down's syndrome.causes: Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused when abnormal cell division results in an extra full or partial copy of chromosome 21. This extra genetic material causes the developmental changes and physical features of Down syndrome.
down's syndrome.consequences:
There are increasing opportunities and support in education, work and housing for people with Down's syndrome. Those with it can live healthy and fulfilling lives as part of their families and communities.
Some health issues can be more common in people with the condition, but some are less common. Regular health checks can make sure any health issues are picked up early and managed.
down's syndrome.prevention:
Down's syndrome is not a life-limiting condition, which means people with it will not lead a shorter life because of the condition.
During pregnancy women will be offered a test to detect if the baby might have Down‚Äôs syndrome.
down's syndrome.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/brain-nerves-and-spinal-cord/downs-syndrome' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

earache.definition: Earache is a common problem, particularly in children. It can be worrying, but it's usually only caused by a minor infection. Earache can be a sharp, dull or burning ear pain that comes and goes or is constant. One or both ears may be affected.
earache.causes:
The most frequent causes for Ear Aches are:
- Ear infections, here may be a watery or pus-like fluid coming out of the ear.
- Glue ear, which is a build-up of fluid deep inside the ear, which commonly causes some temporary hearing loss.
- Damage to the ear, earwax or an object in it and throat infections are also possible conditions that may cause an earache.
earache.consequences:
Treating earache at home isn't hard and can be done with painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat the pain. Placing a warm flannel against the affected ear may also help relieve the pain.
Your pharmacist may be able to recommend over-the-counter eardrops for your earache, but let them know your symptoms and ask for their advice first.
earache.prevention:
Some earaches may be preventable. In order to prevent having a sudden earache, try to keep foreign objects out of the ear and make sure you dry the ears after swimming or bathing.
You should also avoid allergy triggers, such as dust and pollen.
earache.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/ears-nose-and-throat/earache' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

epilepsy.definition: Epilepsy is a condition that affects the brain and causes repeated seizures. The severity of seizures can differ from person to person. Some simply experience an odd feeling with no loss of awareness, or may have a 'trance-like' state for a few seconds or minutes, while others lose consciousness and have convulsions.
epilepsy.causes:
In over half of epilepsy cases, a cause cannot be found. If there is an identifiable cause, it usually involves the brain being affected by a condition.
Epilepsy can start at any age, but it most often begins during childhood.
Epilepsy can be caused by strokes, brain tumours and severe head injuries.
On the other hand, some cases of epilepsy may be caused by changes in the brain that occur as a result of the genes you inherit from your parents.
epilepsy.consequences:
Most people with epilepsy can be successfully treated with AEDs (anti-epileptic drugs). Generally, they work by changing the levels of the chemicals in your brain that conduct electrical impulses. This reduces the chance of a seizurebut doesnot cure epilepsy.
If your epilepsy is still poorly controlled after trying treatment with AEDs, you may be referred to a specialist epilepsy centre to see if you are suitable for surgery to remove the part of your brain causing your seizures.
epilepsy.prevention:
Epilepsy is usually difficult to diagnose quickly. In most cases, it cannot be confirmed until you have had more than one seizure.
An EEG test can detect unusual brain activity associated with epilepsy by measuring the electrical activity of your brain through electrodes placed on your scalp, helping you prevent it.
epilepsy.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/brain-nerves-and-spinal-cord/epilepsy' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

erectile disfunction.definition: Erectile dysfunction, also known as impotence, is the inability to get and maintain an erection. Erectile dysfunction is a very common condition, particularly in older men.
erectile disfunction.causes:
Erectile dysfunction can have many causes, such as certain medical conditions, medications and stress.
There are four main types of health conditions that can cause physical problems resulting in erectile dysfunction. These are the conditions affecting the flow of blood to the penis, conditions affecting the nervous system, conditions affecting hormone levels and conditions affecting the physical structure of the penis.
In some men, certain medicines can cause erectile dysfunction, including diuretics, antihypertensives and antidepressants, among others.
erectile disfunction.consequences:
If you have erectile dysfunction, treatment will depend on what's causing it.
If the erectile dysfunction is caused by an underlying health condition, such as heart disease or diabetes, that condition may need to be treated first.
Erectile dysfunction can often be improved by making changes to your lifestyle, such as losing weight if you are overweight, giving up smoking or cutting back your alcohol consumption.
erectile disfunction.prevention:
Erectile dysfunction can often be diagnosed by your doctor.
A physical examination of the penis may be carried out to rule out anatomical causes.
If you have symptoms of an enlarged prostate, such as weak or irregular urination, a digital rectal examination may be suggested.
Blood tests can also check for underlying health conditions. For example, measuring the levels of hormones such as testosterone can rule out hormonal conditions.
erectile disfunction.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/sexual-and-reproductive/erectile-dysfunction-impotence' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

eye cancer.definition:
There are a number of different types of cancer that affect the eyes, including eye melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, lymphoma and retinoblastoma.
Cancer can also sometimes develop in the tissues surrounding your eyeball or spread to the eye from other parts of the body, such as the lungs or breasts.
eye cancer.causes:
Eye melanoma occurs when the pigment-producing cells in the eyes divide and multiply too rapidly. This produces a lump of tissue known as a tumour.
It's not clear exactly why this occurs, but factors such as lighter eye colour, white or pale skin or overexposure to sunlight may increase the risk of it happening.
The risk of developing eye melanoma also increases with age, with most cases being diagnosed in people in their 50s.
eye cancer.consequences:
Treatment for melanoma of the eye depends on the size and location of the tumour. Treatment aims to conserve the affected eye whenever possible.
The main treatments for eye melanoma are brachytherapy, external radiotherapy, surgery to remove the tumour or part of the eye or the entire emoval of the eye.
Chemotherapy is rarely used for eye melanoma, but may be suitable for other types of eye cancer.
eye cancer.prevention: in order to prevent melanoma of the eye it's likely you'll have to do different tests, including an eye examination (to look at the structures of your eyes in more detail and check for abnormalities), an ultrasound scan of your eye (uses high-frequency sound waves to create an image of the inside of your eye) or a fluorescein angiogram (where photographs of the suspected cancer are taken using a special camera).
eye cancer.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/cancer/cancer-types-in-adults/eye-cancer#causes' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

flu.definition:
Flu is a common infectious viral illness spread by coughs and sneezes. It can be very unpleasant, but you'll usually begin to feel better within about a week.
Flu isn't the same as the common cold. Flu is caused by a different group of viruses and the symptoms tend to start more suddenly, be more severe and last longer.
flu.causes:
The flu virus is contained in the millions of tiny droplets that come out of the nose and mouth when someone who is infected coughs or sneezes.
Anyone who breathes in the droplets can catch flu. You can also catch the virus by touching the surfaces that the droplets have landed on if you pick up the virus on your hands and then touch your nose or mouth.
flu.consequences:
Some of the main symptoms of flu include a fever of 38¬∫C or above, tiredness and weakness, a headache and other general aches and pains.
Flu can make you feel so exhausted and unwell that you have to stay in bed and rest until you feel better.
flu.prevention:
There are 3 main ways of preventing flu which are the flu vaccination, good hygiene (such as handwashing and cleaning) and antiviral medication.
You can also help stop the spread of flu by avoiding unnecessary contact with other people while you're infectious. You should stay off work or school until you're feeling better.
flu.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/infections-and-poisoning/flu#about-flu' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

flatulence.definition: Flatulence is passing gas from the digestive system out of the back passage. It's more commonly known as 'passing wind', or 'farting'.
flatulence.causes: When you swallow food, water or saliva, you also swallow small amounts of air, which collects in the digestive system. Gases can also build up when you digest food. The body needs to get rid of the build-up by farting or burping.
flatulence.consequences:
If your flatulence is particularly troublesome ‚Äì for example, if you're frequently passing smelly gas - make sure to see your doctor.
If your flatulence is troublesome, there are several over-the-counter remedies that can help treat it.
Excessive flatulence can usually be controlled by making changes to your diet.
flatulence.prevention: Excessive flatulence can usually be controlled by making changes to your diet and lifestyle, such as avoiding foods known to cause flatulence, eating smaller and more frequent meals and slowly and exercising regularly.
flatulence.more: You can read more about it <a href='https://www.nhsinform.scot/illnesses-and-conditions/stomach-liver-and-gastrointestinal-tract/flatulence' target='_blank'> here <a/> !

food poisoning.definition:
Food poisoning is an illness caused by eating contaminated food. It's not usually serious and most people get better within a few days without treatment.
In most cases of food poisoning, the food is contaminated by bacteria, such as salmonella or E. coli, or a virus, such as the norovirus.
food poisoning.causes:
Food can become contaminated at any stage during its production, processing or cooking. For example, it can become contaminated by not cooking food thoroughly, not correctly storing food, keeping cooked food unrefrigerated for a long period, eating food that has been touched by someone who is ill or cross-contamination.
Food contamination is usually caused by bacteria, but it can also sometimes be caused by viruses or parasites.
food poisoning.consequences:
Food poisoning can usually be treated at home without seeking medical advice. Most people will feel better within a few days.
It's important to avoid dehydration by drinking plenty of water, as you need to replace any fluids lost through vomiting and diarrhoea.
Also avoid alcohol, caffeine, fizzy drinks and spicy and fatty foods because they may make you feel worse.
If your symptoms are severe or persistent, you may need further treatment and antibiotics may be prescribed if the results show you have a bacterial infection.
food poisoning.prevention:
The best way to avoid getting food poisoning is to ensure you maintain high standards of personal and food hygiene when storing, handling and preparing food.
It's important to cook food thoroughly, particularly meat and most types of seafood, to kill any harmful bacteria that may be present.
Certain foods need to be kept at the correct temperature to prevent harmful bacteria from growing and multiplying. Always check the storage instructions on the label.

fungal nail infection.definition:
Many people develop a fungal nail infection at some point in their life. It's not usually serious, but can be unpleasant and difficult to treat.
The infection develops slowly and causes the nail to become discoloured, thickened and distorted.
The medical name for a fungal nail infection is onychomycosis.
fungal nail infection.causes:
Most fungal nail infections occur as a result of the fungi that cause athlete's foot infecting the nails.
These fungi often live harmlessly on your skin, but they can sometimes multiply and lead to infections. The fungi prefer warm, dark and moist places like the feet.
fungal nail infection.consequences:
Treatment may not be necessary in mild cases of fungal nail infection. For more severe or troublesome cases, antifungal medication may be recommended.
A fungal nail infection is unlikely to get better without treatment, but if you're not bothered by it you might decide it's not worth treating because treatment can take a long time, may cause side effects, and isn't always effective.
fungal nail infection.prevention: You can reduce your risk of developing a fungal nail infection by keeping your hands and feet clean and dry, wearing well-fitting shoes made of natural materials and clean cotton socks, clipping your nails to keep them short, not sharing towels and socks with other people and not walking around barefoot in public pools, showers, and locker rooms.

gastroenteritis.definition:
Gastroenteritis is a very common condition that causes diarrhoea and vomiting. It's usually caused by a bacterial or viral tummy bug.
Gastroenteritis can be very unpleasant, but it usually clears up by itself within a week. You can normally look after yourself or your child at home until you're feeling better.
gastroenteritis.causes: Most cases in children are caused by a virus called rotavirus. Cases in adults are usually caused by norovirus or bacterial food poisoning.
gastroenteritis.consequences: If you have gastroenteritis, drink plenty of fluids, take paracetamol for any fever or aches and pains, if you feel like eating, try small amounts of plain foods, such as soup, rice, pasta and bread or take anti-vomiting medication and/or antidiarrhoeal medication if you need to, in order to help ease your symptoms.
gastroenteritis.prevention:
It's not always possible to avoid getting gastroenteritis. Altought you can follow some advice to help it spreading such as disinfect any surfaces or objects that could be contaminated, wash contaminated items of clothing or bedding separately on a hot wash and practice good food hygiene.
Take extra care when travelling to parts of the world with poor sanitation, as you could pick up a stomach bug. For example, you may need to boil tap water before drinking it.

gum disease.definition:
Gum disease is a very common condition where the gums become swollen, sore or infected.
If you have gum disease, your gums may bleed when you brush your teeth and you may have bad breath. This early stage of gum disease is known as gingivitis.
If gingivitis isn't treated, a condition called periodontitis can develop. This affects more tissues that support teeth and hold them in place.
If periodontitis isn't treated, the bone in your jaw may be damaged and small spaces can open up between the gum and teeth. Your teeth can become loose and may eventually fall out.
gum disease.causes:
Gum disease can be caused by a number of factors, but poor oral hygiene is the most common cause. Poor oral hygiene, such as not brushing your teeth properly or regularly, can cause plaque to build up on your teeth.
Over time, acid in plaque begins to break down your tooth's surface and causes tooth decay. Other bacteria in plaque can also irritate your gums, making them inflamed and sore.
gum disease.consequences:
The best way to treat gum disease is to practise good oral hygiene, although additional dental and medical treatments are sometimes necessary.
Good oral hygiene involves brushing your teeth for about two minutes last thing at night before you go to bed and on one other occasion everyday, flossing your teeth regularly and regularly visiting your dentist.
Some dental treatments may also be recommended if you have gum disease such as Scale and polish, Root planing or Further treatment, like periodontal surgery.
gum disease.prevention: Mild cases of gum disease can usually be prevented by maintaining a good level of oral hygiene. This includes brushing your teeth at least twice a day and flossing regularly. You should also make sure you attend regular dental check-ups.

haemorrhoids.definition:
Haemorrhoids are swellings containing enlarged blood vessels that are found inside or around the bottom (the rectum and anus).
In many cases, haemorrhoids don't cause symptoms, and some people don't even realise they have them. However, when symptoms do occur, they may include bleeding after passing a stool, a lump hanging down outside of the anus or a itchy bottom.
haemorrhoids.causes:
The exact cause of haemorrhoids is unclear, but they're associated with increased pressure in the blood vessels in and around your anus. This pressure can cause the blood vessels in your back passage to become swollen and inflamed.
Factors that might increase your risk of developing haemorrhoids include being overweight or obese, age ‚Äì as you get older, your body's supporting tissues get weaker, having a family history of haemorrhoids or regularly lifting heavy objects.
haemorrhoids.consequences:
Haemorrhoid symptoms often settle down after a few days, without needing treatment. Haemorrhoids that occur during pregnancy often get better after giving birth.
Making lifestyle changes to reduce the strain on the blood vessels in and around your anus is often recommended. Medication that you apply directly to your back passage or tablets bought from a pharmacy or prescribed by your doctor may ease your symptoms and make it easier for you to pass stools.
haemorrhoids.prevention: Gradually increasing the amount of fibre in your diet, drinking plenty of fluid (but avoiding or cutting down on caffeine and alcohol), not delaying going to the toilet and avoiding medication that causes constipation may reduce the risk of haemorrhoids returning, or even developing in the first place.

headache.definition: Headaches are a common health problem ‚Äî most people experience them at some time. In many cases, you can treat your headaches at home with over-the-counter painkillers and lifestyle changes, such as getting more rest and drinking enough fluids.
headache.causes:
A headache can affect any part of the head, and pain may be present in one or several locations.
Tension headaches are the most common type of headache and are what we think of as normal headaches.
Migraines are less common than tension headaches. They're usually felt as a severe, throbbing pain at the front or side of the head.
Cluster headaches are a rare type of headache that are excruciatingly painful, causing intense pain around one eye,.
The exact cause is unclear, but tension headaches have been linked to things such as stress, poor posture, skipping meals and dehydration.
headache.consequences:
Rest and pain relief medication are the main treatments for headaches. Some home remedies to help you treat your headache include using a heat or ice pack against the head or neck, but avoid extreme temperatures, avoid stressors whenever possible, get enough sleep and eat regular meals.
Exercising regularly and limiting alcohol intake are also viable options.
headache.prevention: In order to prevent having a headache, you should get enough sleep and eat regular meals. You should also exercise regularly, limit alcohol intake and avoid stressful situations as much as possible.

hearing loss.definition:
Hearing loss is a common problem that often develops with age or is caused by repeated exposure to loud noises. Hearing loss can occur suddenly, but usually develops gradually.
General signs of hearing loss can include difficulty hearing other people clearly and misunderstanding what they say, asking people to repeat themselves or listening to music or watching television with the volume turned up higher than other people require.
hearing loss.causes:
Hearing loss is the result of sound signals not reaching the brain. There are two main types of hearing loss, depending on where the problem lies:
- sensorineural hearing loss ‚Äì caused by damage to the sensitive hair cells inside the inner ear or damage to the auditory nerve;
- conductive hearing loss ‚Äì when sounds are unable to pass from your outer ear to your inner ear, often because of a blockage such as earwax, glue ear or a build-up of fluid from an ear infection.
hearing loss.consequences:
The way hearing loss is treated depends on the cause and how severe it is. In cases of sensorineural hearing loss, there are several options that may help to improve a person‚Äôs ability to hear and communicate. These include digital hearing aids, bone anchored implants, middle ear implants or lip reading and/or sign language.
Conductive hearing loss is sometimes temporary and can be treated with medication or minor surgery, if necessary. However, more major surgery may be required to fix the ear drum or hearing bones.
hearing loss.prevention:
It isn't always possible to prevent hearing loss if you have an underlying condition that causes you to lose your hearing.
However, there are several things you can do to reduce the risk of hearing loss from long-term exposure to loud noise. This includes not having music or the television on at a loud volume at home and using ear protection at loud music events or in noisy work environments.

heart failure.definition:
Heart failure is a serious condition, but it does not actually mean that your heart has failed. It means that your heart is not pumping blood around your body very efficiently.
The left side of your heart pumps blood to the body including the brain and kidneys. The right heart pumps blood to the lungs. Heart failure can affect the left or the right side of your heart, or both.
heart failure.causes:
In many cases, the cause of heart failure is unknown or uncertain. Conditions that can cause heart failure include heart attack, inherited heart disease, high blood pressure, heart rhythm or valve abnormalities or viral infection and damage from the immune system.
Heart failure on the left side can sometimes lead to heart failure on the right side.
heart failure.consequences:
Heart failure results from impairment of the heart's pumping action. Commonly this is related to heart muscle damage that cannot be repaired. However, many treatments available can help to keep the condition under control and help to relieve the symptoms.
The standard medicines for treating heart failure are angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), beta blockers, diuretics and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs).
A heart transplant may be an option for people with severe heart failure, but it is not an option for everyone. It is also dependant on the availability of a suitable donor heart.
heart failure.prevention:
There are many ways to reduce your chances of heart failure. Here they are:
- Avoid smoking and drinking excessive amounts of alcohol;
- Take regular exercise and Eat a healthy diet;
- If you have high blood pressure, maintain good control of it;
- If you are diabetic, maintain good control of it and always attend review appointments.

hepatitis A.definition: Hepatitis A is a liver infection caused by a virus that's spread in the poo of an infected person. Hepatitis A can be unpleasant, but it's not usually serious and most people make a full recovery within a couple of months. A hepatitis A vaccine is available for people at a high risk of infection.
hepatitis A.causes:
Hepatitis A is caused by the hepatitis A virus, which is spread in the poo of someone with the infection. Most infections occur in parts of the world where standards of sanitation and food hygiene are generally poor.
You can get hepatitis A from eating food prepared by someone infected, drinking or eating raw/undercooked shellfish from contaminated water, close contact with someone who has hepatitis A or injecting drugs using equipment contaminated with the virus.
hepatitis A.consequences:
There's currently no cure for hepatitis A, but it will normally pass on its own within a couple of months. You can usually look after yourself at home.
Relieving your symptoms can be done by get plenty of rest, especially during the initial stages of the infection, taking painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen if you have any aches and pains, reduce itching by maintaining a cool, well-ventilated environment and eat smaller, ligther meals and avoid alchool.
hepatitis A.prevention:
Vaccination against hepatitis A it's only recommended for people at high risk.
People usually advised to have the hepatitis A vaccine include close contacts of someone with hepatitis A, people planning to travel to or live in parts of the world where hepatitis A is widespread, people who may be exposed to hepatitis A through their job or people with any type of long-term (chronic) liver disease.

hepatitis B.definition:
Hepatitis B is an infection of the liver caused by a virus that's spread through blood and body fluids.
It often doesn't cause any obvious symptoms in adults and typically passes in a few months without treatment, but in children it often persists for years and may eventually cause serious liver damage.
hepatitis B.causes:
Hepatitis B is an infection caused by the hepatitis B virus. The virus is found in the blood and bodily fluids of an infected person.
Many people with hepatitis B have few symptoms and may not know they're infected. They may spread the infection without realising it.
Hepatitis B can be spread by a mother to their baby, injecting drugs and sharing needles and other drug equipment, having unprotected sex with an infected person, sharing toothbrushes or razors contaminated with infected blood or having a blood transfusion in a country where blood isn't tested for hepatitis B.
hepatitis B.consequences:
Treatment for hepatitis B depends on how long you've been infected for.
Short-term (acute) hepatitis B doesn't usually need specific treatment, but may require treatment to relieve the symptoms (rest, painkillers, cool, well-ventilated environment or medication such as metoclopramide to stop you feeling sick and chlorphenamine to reduce itching).
Long-term (chronic) hepatitis B is often treated with medication to keep the virus under control. The main medicines for chronic hepatitis B include Peginterferon alfa-2a (stimulates the immune system) or Antiviral medicines.
hepatitis B.prevention:
A vaccine that offers protection against hepatitis B is available for babies and for people at high risk of the infection or complications from it.
If you're travelling to a part of the world where hepatitis B is widespread or work somewhere that places them at risk of contact with blood or body fluids, such as nurses, prison staff, doctors, dentists and laboratory staff, or have a chronic liver/kidney disease you're included in people at high risk of the infection and can take the vaccine.
